DataElement.preferredName: Book Randomization Allocation Plan Study Activity Description ISO21090.ST.v1.0
DataElement.preferredDefinition: An activity that is intended to occur at some point in the course of a particular study and that is the assignment of an experimental unit to a portion of the study, such as an arm or a portion of an arm (when secondary allocations may occur) based on a randomization book. NOTE(S): A randomization book is a predefined set of assignments to portions of a study based on criteria, such as stratum group for example, that ensures a desired distribution of subjects across those portions of the study. For example, the book entries indicate which arm a given subject, Joe, is assigned to based on the fact that he's the 5th person in stratum group #2. The textual representation of the planned activity. EXAMPLE(S): In a migraine trial, the Wait activity may have a description of "Wait until first grade 2 or 3 migraine".

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Book Randomization Allocation Plan Study Activity Description
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A volume made up of pages fastened along one edge and enclosed between protective covers. (from American Heritage Dictionary):The allocation of individuals to groups by chance, especially in order to control the variables in an experiment.:The distribution of resources over various time periods, products, operations, or investments.:To devise, contrive, or formed in design.:A detailed examination, analysis, or critical inspection of a subject designed to discover facts about it.:An action taken in pursuit of an objective._A statement or an account describing something.

Concepts.definition: A volume made up of pages fastened along one edge and enclosed between protective covers. (from American Heritage Dictionary)
The allocation of individuals to groups by chance, especially in order to control the variables in an experiment.
The distribution of resources over various time periods, products, operations, or investments.
To devise, contrive, or form in design.
A detailed examination, analysis, or critical inspection of a subject designed to discover facts about it.
An active process; excludes processes and mechanisms which fulfill biological functions.
